folder: Charlton Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Charlton Street, north side, west from and including Greenwich Street, to and including West Street, showing in the foreground the clearing where the Standard Statistics Building (see Hudson Street) will rise. No. 11 Charlton Street, adjoining 551 Greenwich Street, the house at the N.E. corner, is the only Charlton Street house left in this block.

Demolition of the warehouses, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Washington Street, will begin in July of this year (see West Street).

April 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Charlton Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
102 to 112 Charlton Street, east of and including the S.E. corner of Greenwich Street, seen from the clearing on the north side of Charlton Street.

April 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Charlton Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Charlton Street, north side, from Greenwich to West Streets, inclusive, showing the vacant lot at 554 Greenwich Street, the four old houses 113-119 Charlton Street, east of and at Washington Street, and the warehouses at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Washington Street, which are to be demolished immediately, being included in the site of the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal.  Charlton Street will be permanently closed from Washington to West Streets.

July 25, 1930
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
113-119 and 121-137 Charlton Street, north side, from Greenwich Street towards West Street, a view included in the above picture.

July 25, 1930
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Charlton Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Charlton Street, north side, from Greenwich to Hudson Streets, inclusive.
March 19, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Charlton Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Charlton Street, east from Greenwich Street. The elevated structure shown on the latter is the Ninth Ave. system.

September 1, 1934.

Irvin Fitterman.

folder: Charlton Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Charlton Street, north side, and west of Greenwich Street.

P. L. Sperr

May 5, 1941

(1) and (2)
Transportation--Trucks: Heavy trucks engaged in the out-of-town transport trade, seen at Greenwich and Charlton Streets and at the S.E. corner of Greenwich and 13th Streets, Manhattan.

P. L. Sperr

(3)
Coal delivery trucks at 1568 Second Avenue, Manhattan.

P. L. Sperr
1941
